5 Minutes of Garrett talking about his

(stuff)

Good morning everyone. Is it sarcastic to say "good" morning to someone on a Monday morning?

Today I will spend 5 minutes talking about my shit (research shit).

I recently got very interested in the idea of mapping human behavior, and what sorts of things we could find out by doing so.

What would even be mapped really?

Could behavior even properly be mapped?

Well turns out, people's stress can be mapped to measure how people respond to the environment, but properly? well kinda

People are complex, and so is their behavior. Meaning we cant just rely on one data source to properly study it. And its even worse if we used traditional visalization methods. Here's what I mean.

GPS & Stress Data

This is the cycling data i think most are familiar with?

Which is showing a timeline of someone's GPS & stress levels.

What can you tell from it?

Speed, Elevation, and stress levels.

Not much. Traditional data visualizations dont give us the context these stress levels occured, which is the most important factor.

Sow what about the thing we like most, a map?

A map would show where people went, what kind of places they went through, And how they felt while doing it.

Mapping Emotion

I've never been more dissapointed in a map.

Our knowledge of the context is still bad. So what about some first person POV of the person showing those stress levels? That'd give us some better context right?
Well this is useless. We know nothing about their stress levels now.

And unfortunately, we cant just do this.


:)

But, this is what we would kind of want right? Something to display all data at once, in the context the data is occuring in.
Interaction = Major ðŸ”‘
Due to these issues,

I made an app which can be used to look at where people are feeling things, and really zoom in on it, so that a manager can go, "Ok, a person felt something here, whats there??"

But, researchers can also use it to discover interesting patterns when exploring newly collected data, to then better direct where they should focus their research efforts.

The really cool thing about this approach is that it can be applied to similar scenarios, like how people are experiencing and reacting to a museum's exhibits.

And this is important because when spatially analyzing human behavior, you will always run into the same issues... insufficient data visualizations.

I got 99 problems and they all insufficient data visualizations
